content: 1st: Thanks for reading this a giving your opinions. All input is greatly appreciated. I am 23 yrs old, single, no children. I have decided that I will enlist, and have narrowed my choices to the Air Force and Marine Corp. I've researched both over the last few weeks but I I just can't decide. I hear that the AF is the easiest of all branches and that they provide more technical training. I also found that Airmen have more time available to them outside their assigned duties. As my AF recruiter put it, "You are able to 'live life' when not on duty. I like the Marine Corp because I know it would be the greatest challenge, and if I can become a Marine, I should be able to anything. Also, there is something about the Dress Blues that makes it all seem worth it. But I also hear that Marines are married to the Corp, leaving little time for outside life. I would like to go to school, but it's not my biggest concern, and I'm not scared of being deployed. My biggest fear is picking one and wishing I chose the other. I need some more points of view before I can make this decision. Thanks again for you input. Thx -a future Airman or Marine

I need some more points of view before I can make this decision. Thanks again for you input. Thx -a future Airman or Marine What type of person are YOU, and what do YOU want to become?? That is what should be governing your choices, not what someone else thinks or sees as best, especially at 23. You're old enough to make a choice and live with it. If you want to be tough and do tough, hard dirty, mean work the right way, then you should look and Army Infantry/Airborne/Special Forces, Navy Seals, or Marines. They all do that, and they do it right. If you want Combat Arms, but don't want to walk everywhere, then you should look at Army Armor/Artillery, or the same thing in Marines. If you want to see all parts of the world in one enlistment, the Navy can do that. If you want a lot of technical training, be around jets, work on 'em that stuff - now you're pretty much headed for Air Force and Navy.... The point is - What appeals the most to you??? When I was young, I wanted rough and tumble combat arms, but had a slightly game knee, so I enlisted Armor, and did some Combat Engineers towards the end. When I got older, and very tired of mud, I switched to Air Force and Radar - got great technical training and had a lot of good times, but slept a whole lot less on the ground or in tents - - You got to go for what YOU WANT! Otherwise, you'll never be satisfied, and probably end up hating it - - Wandering and Wondering

content: thekingof118, unless your planning on making the military a career where you can retire after 20 years and have a decent pension and still be young enough to go back to the work force, find what interest you and see if the mos translate to a civilian job, combat arms does not translate well, and its harder to find a good paying job once out, even in the military as you progress in rank the military loves that you keep educcating yourself, the more schooling you get the better the promotions, the marine corp does not help much in taking college classes especially if your in the combat arms, there is not much time for it, if your in a mos that has you in the rear with the gear more, then you can get some time to take classes, but marine battlions alwasy deploy every 18 months for 6 months. the air force is high tech heavy and so many of there jobs will translate into good paying jobs in the civilian sector, I enjoyed my time being a marine but when i got out there was not much open to me. so think hard before you decide, a 20 year career in the corp would look good on your resume but just a 4 year tour in combat arms isn't going to give you much.

content: Scout's got it right. After and enlistment in combat arms (Armor/Combat Engineers), I could shoot expert with anything I could pick up or get into the turret of, I could throw a handgrenade into a bucket from 60 yards, I could lay mines and pick 'em up, blow up anything and everything with TNT C-4 and ammonium nitrate, call in artillery or TAC air to blow stuff up for me, etc etc - but there wasn't a lot of call for that when I got out. I thought about going Police or Bomb Squad, but my wife had a fit! She spent 6 years expecting me to get blown up and couldn't take it any more... If yer looking for civilian follow-on, tech is the way to go, and you've already got a leg up because of computer skills - Go Intelligence, sneak and peek. Even CIA - - If you want "Fun Travel and Adventure" - Straight Leg Infantry or Armor Recon will put you in the middle of it these days - just keep you weapon handy and your helmet on, even when sleeping or taking a dump!!! Wandering and Wondering

I need some more points of view before I can make this decision. Thanks again for you input. Thx -a future Airman or Marine I think you're getting some good advice here. Many new posters come in here as ask this question. It is very difficult for us to give you an unbiased answer but also difficult because only you really know what your interests are. Ex: go Infantry just because a bunch of us say it's a great job may not be a good fit for you. One bit of advice I saw was great....you may want to think about an MOS based on how it would translate to a job post military....or maybe you just need to do what you want most and let the post military thing play out later. I wouldn't get too caught up in the "Dress Blues" though I agree that they are, in my opinion, the best uniform we have in the different branches. My son has been an Active Duty Marine for three years now and has worn his on very rare occasions. Another thing, "deployment", he has yet to be deployed anywhere though he says he has asked to. He's a Corporal, Mechanic/Crew on the Amphibious Assault Vehicles. I don't think I've ever heard my son complain about lack of social life, then again, you're probably going to get a different opinion from any Marine in Iraq or Afghanistan. I grew up next to a USAF SAC Base in NH and have alway had a great respect for them. That brings up another subject. You may want to be stationed somewhere up North and though there may be USMC bases in the North, I can not think of any off the top of my head. I believe in the USAF you could be assigned to Alaska if that is something you are interested in....not me, I prefer warmth! Like I said, I grew up next to a USAF base, my son is a US Marine, but....both my brother and I went US Coast Guard because we both knew we wanted to be Coxswains and run the SAR boats. Best of luck in your difficult decision and hopefully your future in the Military if that is what you end up doing. Don

That is what should be governing your choices, not what someone else thinks or sees as best, especially at 23. You're old enough to make a choice and live with it. If you want to be tough and do tough, hard dirty, mean work the right way, then you should look and Army Infantry/Airborne/Special Forces, Navy Seals, or Marines. They all do that, and they do it right. If you want Combat Arms, but don't want to walk everywhere, then you should look at Army Armor/Artillery, or the same thing in Marines. If you want to see all parts of the world in one enlistment, the Navy can do that. If you want a lot of technical training, be around jets, work on 'em that stuff - now you're pretty much headed for Air Force and Navy.... The point is - What appeals the most to you??? When I was young, I wanted rough and tumble combat arms, but had a slightly game knee, so I enlisted Armor, and did some Combat Engineers towards the end. When I got older, and very tired of mud, I switched to Air Force and Radar - got great technical training and had a lot of good times, but slept a whole lot less on the ground or in tents - - You got to go for what YOU WANT! Otherwise, you'll never be satisfied, and probably end up hating it - - Wandering and Wondering

content: thekingof118, unless your planning on making the military a career where you can retire after 20 years and have a decent pension and still be young enough to go back to the work force, find what interest you and see if the mos translate to a civilian job, combat arms does not translate well, and its harder to find a good paying job once out, even in the military as you progress in rank the military loves that you keep educcating yourself, the more schooling you get the better the promotions, the marine corp does not help much in taking college classes especially if your in the combat arms, there is not much time for it, if your in a mos that has you in the rear with the gear more, then you can get some time to take classes, but marine battlions alwasy deploy every 18 months for 6 months. the air force is high tech heavy and so many of there jobs will translate into good paying jobs in the civilian sector, I enjoyed my time being a marine but when i got out there was not much open to me. so think hard before you decide, a 20 year career in the corp would look good on your resume but just a 4 year tour in combat arms isn't going to give you much.

After and enlistment in combat arms (Armor/Combat Engineers), I could shoot expert with anything I could pick up or get into the turret of, I could throw a handgrenade into a bucket from 60 yards, I could lay mines and pick 'em up, blow up anything and everything with TNT C-4 and ammonium nitrate, call in artillery or TAC air to blow stuff up for me, etc etc - but there wasn't a lot of call for that when I got out. Even CIA - - If you want "Fun Travel and Adventure" - Straight Leg Infantry or Armor Recon will put you in the middle of it these days - just keep you weapon handy and your helmet on, even when sleeping or taking a dump!!! Wandering and Wondering

Many new posters come in here as ask this question. It is very difficult for us to give you an unbiased answer but also difficult because only you really know what your interests are. Ex: go Infantry just because a bunch of us say it's a great job may not be a good fit for you. One bit of advice I saw was great....you may want to think about an MOS based on how it would translate to a job post military....or maybe you just need to do what you want most and let the post military thing play out later. I wouldn't get too caught up in the "Dress Blues" though I agree that they are, in my opinion, the best uniform we have in the different branches. My son has been an Active Duty Marine for three years now and has worn his on very rare occasions. Another thing, "deployment", he has yet to be deployed anywhere though he says he has asked to. He's a Corporal, Mechanic/Crew on the Amphibious Assault Vehicles. I don't think I've ever heard my son complain about lack of social life, then again, you're probably going to get a different opinion from any Marine in Iraq or Afghanistan. I grew up next to a USAF SAC Base in NH and have alway had a great respect for them. That brings up another subject. You may want to be stationed somewhere up North and though there may be USMC bases in the North, I can not think of any off the top of my head. I believe in the USAF you could be assigned to Alaska if that is something you are interested in....not me, I prefer warmth! Like I said, I grew up next to a USAF base, my son is a US Marine, but....both my brother and I went US Coast Guard because we both knew we wanted to be Coxswains and run the SAR boats. Best of luck in your difficult decision and hopefully your future in the Military if that is what you end up doing. Don
